Dear all: Here is an interesting question from a classmate, along with a discussion from me. You are all welcome to continue the discussion if interested.

***
I am confused about two concepts, philosophy and religious belief. According to the content of the lecture, it seems that we should use logical reasoning to inquire and deal with philosophical problems/questions. But my doubt is that this is kind of a belief in "logic". For instance, we believe that logic is the fundamental principle to solve all problems. Then, if I attempt to use a logical argument to justify this belief, it will become a "circular argument" -- like using a logical method to justify logic. So might philosophy just be a kind of belief like some other religious beliefs? How do we explain why we should use logical reasoning?

***

Thanks for this very deep question.

One issue you raise concerns how to distinguish the results of philosophical inquiry from religious belief. Another is whether relying on logic is circular in some way.

Ideally, philosophy is distinguished from religion by its reliance on critical thinking (批判思考) and its avoidance of appeals to dogma (教條) or faith (信仰). In practice, philosophical inquiry may not always live up to this ideal. But when it falls short, all parties to a philosophical discussion are expected to acknowledge that appeals to dogma or faith are not good grounds for belief or action. In principle, in philosophy everything is open to question.

Of course, any philosophical position must provisionally accept some beliefs or values as starting premises, which in a particular context do not require justification unless we can identify good reasons to challenge them. But one feature distinctive of philosophical discourse is that even our starting premises are in principle open to critical evaluation and can possibly be rejected. Our acceptance of any premise is always open-ended and provisional. This is usually not the case with religious belief.

Critical thinking revolves around an activity that Wilfrid Sellars, a famous 20th-century philosopher, called "the game of giving and asking for reasons." A basic rule of critical thinking is that beliefs and actions must be supported by reasons. Logic is largely the study of how reasons (理由) can support assertions (斷言) or claims (宣稱) -- that is, sentences (句子) or propositions (命題) that we state are correct or true. (This is why logic is often called "the study of inference" -- 推理之學 or 理則學. Inference refers to relations by which different beliefs or claims may support or refute each other.) So if we're going to give reasons for what we think, say, or do, we will often need to employ logic.

This need not be a circular or question-begging move, because we need not assume that logical norms are beyond doubt. We're free to inquire into the basic rules of logic, explain why we accept them, and in some cases perhaps revise them. (This is one reason why logicians have developed non-classical and paraconsistent logics.) But if we're using logic in the context of giving reasons for beliefs or claims, cases in which we have grounds for revising classical rules of inference will be very rare.

(continued)

It might look like a commitment to critical thinking and logic is equivalent to a commitment to a religion, a political ideology, or some other creed. But critical thinking is a kind of activity, not a particular set of beliefs or doctrines. So a commitment to trying understand things and justify beliefs or values through philosophical inquiry is not directly comparable to believing in a particular religion or ideology.

Still, we might ask: why commit to the activity or the life of settling questions through critical thinking? Isn't that commitment just another ideology? When we look at what's actually involved in critical thinking, however, really this is just a commitment to doing our best to make sure our beliefs and values are true, right, or well justified. Even people with beliefs or ideologies very different from ours tend to want to claim their views are true or right. So we could argue that since others also endorse the importance of truth, rightness, and justification, our commitment to critical thinking is probably not unfairly circular or illegitimately biased.

Those are my initial thoughts. Others on this mailing list are welcome to follow up with more questions or responses.

Dr. Fraser
